awd_titl_txt: Diffusing Colloidal Probe Microscopy of Zwitterionic Nanoparticles
awd_abstract_narration:
Part I: Non-technical summary
Recent attempts to mimic the anti-biofouling properties of the external membrane of mammalian cells on synthetic substrates are increasingly relying on the use of zwitterionic-based materials, i.e., those bearing positively and negatively charged groups. In the context of biomaterials intended for drug delivery applications, surface modification methods that preclude aggregation, precipitation or clearance of diagnostic or therapeutic nanoparticles are particularly important to extend their circulation time in the body, and allow them to accumulate at specific sites through active targeting. Despite the tremendous potential of zwitterionic-based materials, little is known regarding weak interactions between particles and cells due to the limited sensitivity of existing techniques. In this work, the PIs will measure nanometer scale interactions between cells and zwitterionic-decorated particles using non-intrusive microscopy measurements of particle trajectories and analyses that reveal weak interactions. The PIs will use this method to evaluate interactions between nanoparticles functionalized with zwitterionic polymers with well-defined molecular architectures and cell surfaces. Outreach efforts will involve participation of undergraduate students in research, and community involvement through an education-based Latino outreach program and STEM Achievement in Baltimore Elementary Schools.

Part II: Technical summary
The proposed research will provide fundamental and technological insights into the molecular and processing parameters that produce zwitterionic (ZI) particles having the desired combination of specific and non-specific kT-scale interactions with various biomaterials. Non-specific repulsion between zwitterionic species and biomaterials will be understood, designed, optimized by controlling molecular architecture and structure, which will be quantitatively connected to direct sensitive measurements and models. Specific interactions to be investigated include sigma receptor-anisamide and CD44-hyaluronic acid interactions. The work proposed is divided into four tasks. The first deals with ZI polymer design, synthesis and characterization. The goal is to produce a library of materials with increasing architectural complexity that should translate into distinct surface properties. The second task is to examine ZI particle formation through either copolymer adsorption onto silica particles or self-assembly of highly branched amphiphilic macromolecules using processing conditions to affect ZI particle surface properties. The third task is to carry out diffusing probe measurements of ZI particles with model synthetic substrates, to ultimately establish the combination of polymer architecture and adsorption/self-assembly conditions that will result in desired non-specific repulsion. Having established this, the last task of this proposal is to use this knowledge to carry out diffusing probe measurements of specific interactions between ZI particles decorated with specific moieties and cancer cells. Such measurements will be performed for breast cancer cells to study interactions between hyaluronic acid and CD44 receptors, as well as, anisamide and sigma receptors. Each of the four tasks is part of an overarching plan to measure and interpret how particle-cell interactions are influenced by covalent attachment, orientation, and organization on synthetic and cell surfaces in nanobiotechnological applications.

por.por_cntn:
Polymers adsorbed to substrates are commonly used to modulate the surface properties of a material, leaving its bulk properties intact. This can be used to modify the wettability of a material, its adhesion properties, its biocompatibility, etc. Polymer adsorption can also be used to prevent colloidal aggregation or aggregation of colloids with other solvated species. 

In the case of drug carriers (i.e., particles used to deliver drugs and/or imaging agents), precluding aggregation is important, but it is equally important to prevent them from depositing on tissues, or prevent proteins from adsorbing to them, as this would lead to an undesirable cascade of events that ultimately reduce the drug’s efficacy. In this respect, hydrophilic polymers are used to “decorate” the surfaces of drug carriers, endowing them with biological stealthiness.

Poly(ethylene glycol) [PEG] has, for many years, been a benchmark for hydrophilic surface coatings, however there is growing evidence demonstrating that polyzwitterions —polymers that bear an equal number of positive and negative charges— outperform PEG in many aspects, including resistance to non-specific protein adsorption from plasma and blood serum. 

The work developed under this grant dealt with understanding how zwitterionic polymers interact with cells and proteins as part of developing therapeutic and diagnostic particle-based biomaterials. The zwitterionic polymers in question were based on phosphatidylcholines and sulfobetaine functionalities. The former are found in biological membranes, such as those of cells and microorganisms. The latter functionality has an inverse charge arrangement to the former, enabling us to evaluate the role of charge orientation on interactions. 

Under this grant, we have successfully:

1) Surface-adsorbed zwitterionic copolymers based on phosphatidylcholine and sulfobetaine with a triblock or a pentablock arrangement. Triblock (A-B-A) and pentablock (A-R-B-R-A) copolymers were synthesized by controlled polymerization methods to obtain polymers with well-defined molecular structure, wherein the A block is a polyzwitterion (PMPC or PMAPS), B is a hydrophobic block (poly(propylene oxide)), and R is a reactive middle block (alkyne-containing). Both copolymers were designed so as to adsorb to hydrophobic surfaces through block B, exposing the polyzwitterionic  A block to the aqueous environment. Both A-B-A and A-R-B-R-A arrangements showed a high density of surface A-blocks, effectively passivating underlying surface.

2) Implemented diffusing colloidal probe microscopy (DCPM) to measure interactions between these zwitterionic materials and various biologically-relevant solvated species, including proteins, under different physiologically-relevant aqueous environments. DCPM is a highly sensitive technique which provides direct and non-intuitive measurements of kT- and nanometer-scale interactions. Through a systematic study of different polyzwitterions (and PEG as a reference), we established how pH, ionic strength, ion type, polymer molecular weight, and zwitterion type, determine polymer interactions, dimensions, solution behavior, and their role in colloidal stability.

The intellectual merit of the proposed research is related to the fundamental and technological insights that will be gained on the structure-function relationships between polymeric zwitterionic materials and their ability to stabilize and specifically target coated colloids against proteins, cells, and biomaterials.

The broader impacts of the proposed research include scientific and technological outcomes as well as integrated education and outreach activities. Under this award, we have trained 2 Ph.D. and 2 B.S. students. We have also integrated zwitterionic polymer synthesis and properties of their nanoparticles into graduate elective content. Finally, we have done outreach activities with students from the Colorado-Wyoming Alliance for Minority Participation for transfer student recruitment and research.
